message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Constrained Markov Decision Processes
Paper Abstract: This report presents a unified approach for the study of constrained Markov decision processes with a countable state space and unbounded costs. We consider a single controller having several objectives; it is desirable to design a controller that minimize one of cost objective, subject to inequality constraints on other cost objectives. The objectives that we study are both the expected average cost, as well as the expected total cost (of which the discounted cost is a special case). We provide two frameworks: the case were costs are bounded below, as well as the contracting framework. We characterize the set of achievable expected occupation measures as well as performance vectors. This allows us to reduce the original control dynamic problem into an infinite Linear Programming. We present a Lagrangian approach that enables us to obtain sensitivity analysis. In particular, we obtain asymptotical results for the constrained control problem: convergence of both the value and the pol...
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

Web search results for query: "Sensitivity Analysis"

Links: [{"title":"Sensitivity analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_analysis"},{"title":"Variance-based sensitivity analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variance-based_sensitivity_analysis"},{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis to business - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_to_business"},{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis to model calibration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_to_model_calibration"},{"title":"Sensitivity analysis of an EnergyPlus model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_analysis_of_an_EnergyPlus_model"},{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis to multi-criteria decision making - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_to_multi-criteria_decision_making"},{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis in epidemiology - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_in_epidemiology"},{"title":"Category:Sensitivity analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Sensitivity_analysis"},{"title":"Talk:Sensitivity analysis - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Sensitivity_analysis"},{"title":"Applications of sensitivity analysis to environmental sciences - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_sensitivity_analysis_to_environmental_sciences"}]

Here are the key findings about Sensitivity Analysis from the web search results:

## Definition

Sensitivity analysis is the study of how the uncertainty in the output of a mathematical modelor system can be divided and allocated to different sources of uncertainty in its inputs.(no content)This involves estimating sensitivity indices that quantify the influence of an input or group of inputs on the output.

## Key Purposes

In models involving many input variables, sensitivity analysis can help test the robustness of model results in the presence of uncertainty, increase understanding of relationships between input and output variables, and identify model inputs that cause significant uncertainty in the output.

## Common Approaches

Variance-based sensitivity analysis (often referred to as the Sobol' method) is a form of global sensitivity analysis that decomposes the variance of the model output into fractions which can be attributed to inputs or sets of inputs.

## Business Applications

Sensitivity analysis can be applied to business problems, allowing identification of variables which may influence a business decision such as an investment, and helping analysts identify cost drivers and other quantities for which better knowledge is needed to make an informed decision.

## Additional Applications

Sensitivity analysis has practical uses across various fields including model calibration, environmental sciences, epidemiology, building energy simulation, and multi-criteria decision making.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

Sensitivity analysis is the study of how the uncertainty in the output of a mathematical modelor system can be divided and allocated to different sources of uncertainty in its inputs.(no content)This involves estimating sensitivity indices that quantify the influence of an input or group of inputs on the output.

## Key Purposes

In models involving many input variables, sensitivity analysis can help test the robustness of model results in the presence of uncertainty, increase understanding of relationships between input and output variables, and identify model inputs that cause significant uncertainty in the output.

## Common Approaches

Variance-based sensitivity analysis (often referred to as the Sobol' method) is a form of global sensitivity analysis that decomposes the variance of the model output into fractions which can be attributed to inputs or sets of inputs.

## Business Applications

Sensitivity analysis can be applied to business problems, allowing identification of variables which may influence a business decision such as an investment, and helping analysts identify cost drivers and other quantities for which better knowledge is needed to make an informed decision.

## Additional Applications

Sensitivity analysis has practical uses across various fields including model calibration, environmental sciences, epidemiology, building energy simulation, and multi-criteria decision making.

## Search Results for "Linear Programming"

Here's a summary of the search results about Linear Programming:

### Definition
Linear programming (LP), also called linear optimization, is a method to achieve the best outcome (such as maximum profit or lowest cost) in a mathematical model whose requirements and objective are represented by linear relationships.(no content)More formally, linear programming is a technique for the optimization of a linear objective function, subject to linear equality and linear inequality constraints.

### Applications
Industries that use linear programming models include transportation, energy, telecommunications, and manufacturing. It has proven useful in modeling diverse types of problems in planning, routing, scheduling, assignment, and design.

### Historical Development
In the late 1930s, Soviet mathematician Leonid Kantorovich and American economist Wassily Leontief independently delved into the practical applications of linear programming. Kantorovich focused on manufacturing schedules, while Leontief explored economic applications.(no content)From 1946 to 1947 George B. Dantzig independently developed general linear programming formulation to use for planning problems in the US Air Force. In 1947, Dantzig also invented the simplex method that, for the first time efficiently, tackled the linear programming problem in most cases.

### Fundamental Theorem
The fundamental theorem of linear programming states that the maxima and minima of a linear function over a convex polygonal region occur at the region's corners.

The search results cover various aspects of linear programming including its mathematical foundations, historical development, practical applications, and related concepts like linear programming relaxation and multi-objective linear programming.

Links: [{"title":"Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Partially observable Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Partially_observable_Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Decentralized partially observable Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Decentralized_partially_observable_Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Talk:Markov decision process - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Markov_decision_process"},{"title":"Markov model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_model"},{"title":"Category:Markov processes - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Category:Markov_processes"},{"title":"Online optimization - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Online_optimization"}]

## Markov Decision Process

Here's what I found about Markov Decision Processes:

### Overview

A Markov decision process is a Markov chain in which state transitions depend on the current state and an action vector that is applied to the system.(no content)Typically, a Markov decision process is used to compute a policy of actions that will maximize some utility with respect to expected rewards.

### Name and Concept

The name comes from its connection to Markov chains, a concept developed by the Russian mathematician Andrey Markov, and the "Markov" in "Markov decision process" refers to the underlying structure of state transitions that still follow the Markov property.(no content)The process is called a "decision process" because it involves making decisions that influence these state transitions, extending the concept of a Markov chain into the realm of decision-making under uncertainty.

### Time-Based Variations

In discrete-time Markov Decision Processes, decisions are made at discrete time intervals.(no content)For continuous-time Markov decision processes, decisions can be made at any time the decision maker chooses, and they can better model the decision-making process for a system that has continuous dynamics, and this modelling framework can be applied to areas such as queueing systems, epidemic processes, and population processes.

### Related Variants

A partially observable Markov decision process (POMDP) is a generalization of a Markov decision process (MDP) that models an agent decision process in which the system dynamics are determined by an MDP, but the agent cannot directly observe the underlying state.

Web search results for query: "Lagrange multiplier"

Links: [{"title":"Lagrange multiplier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_multiplier"},{"title":"Lagrange multipliers on Banach spaces - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_multipliers_on_Banach_spaces"},{"title":"Talk:Lagrange multiplier - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lagrange_multiplier"},{"title":"Talk:Lagrange multiplier/Archive 1 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Lagrange_multiplier/Archive_1"},{"title":"Score test - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Score_test"},{"title":"Lagrangian relaxation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrangian_relaxation"},{"title":"Theory of functional connections - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Theory_of_functional_connections"}]

## Lagrange Multiplier

In mathematical optimization, the method of Lagrange multipliers is a strategy for finding the local maxima and minima of a function subject to equation constraints (i.e., subject to the condition that one or more equations have to be satisfied exactly by the chosen values of the variables).

### How It Works

The method relies on the intuition that at a maximum, a function cannot be increasing in the direction of any neighboring point that also satisfies the constraints. If it were, one could walk along the constraint to get higher, meaning that the starting point wasn't actually the maximum.

### Applications

The method has broad applications across multiple fields:

- **Economics & Optimization**: The optimal value of a Lagrange multiplier has an interpretation as the marginal effect of the corresponding constraint constant upon the optimal attainable value of the original objective function.

- **Physics**: In Lagrangian mechanics, equations of motion are derived by finding stationary points of the action, and the force on a particle can be interpreted as a Lagrange multiplier determining the change in action.

- **Multiple Constraints**: The method can be extended to solve problems with multiple constraints using a similar argument.

### Extensions

The method has also been generalized to handle more complex scenarios, such as constrained optimization problems on Banach spaces, which is a generalization of the classical method of Lagrange multipliers for finitely many variables.

Web search results for query: "Countable set mathematics"

Links: [{"title":"Countable set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Countable_set"},{"title":"Talk:Countable set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Countable_set"},{"title":"Uncountable set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Uncountable"},{"title":"Cardinality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cardinality"},{"title":"Talk:Uncountable set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Uncountable_set"},{"title":"Enumeration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_(composition)"},{"title":"Infinite set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Infinite_set"},{"title":"Finite set - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Finite_set"},{"title":"Cocountability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Co-countable"},{"title":"Axiom of countability - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Axiom_of_countability"}]

Based on the search results, here's what you should know about countable sets in mathematics:

## Definition

In mathematics, a set is countable if either it is finite or it can be made in one to one correspondence with the set of natural numbers.(no content)Equivalently, a set is countable if there exists an injective function from it into the natural numbers.

## Key Examples

The set of all even integers is a countably infinite set, even if it is a proper subset of the integers. Similarly, the set of all rational numbers is a countably infinite set as there is a bijection to the set of integers.

## Relationship to Uncountable Sets

Not all infinite sets are countable. Countably infinite sets are in one-to-one correspondence with the integers, while the real numbers cannot be put into one-to-one correspondence with the natural numbers.(no content)The set of real numbers has a greater cardinality than the set of natural numbers and is said to be uncountable.

## Historical Context

In 1874, in his first set theory article, Cantor proved that the set of real numbers is uncountable, thus showing that not all infinite sets are countable.

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Discounted Cash Flow cost"

Links: [{"title":"Discounted cash flow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounted_cash_flow"},{"title":"Valuation using discounted cash flows - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Valuation_using_discounted_cash_flows"},{"title":"Talk:Discounted cash flow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Discounted_cash_flow"},{"title":"Net present value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Net_present_value"},{"title":"Discounting - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discount_factor"},{"title":"Terminal value (finance) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Terminal_value_(finance)"},{"title":"Income approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Income_approach"},{"title":"Free cash flow - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Free_cash_flow"},{"title":"Talk:Valuation using discounted cash flows - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Valuation_using_discounted_cash_flows"},{"title":"Discounted payback period - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounted_payback_period"}]

Based on the search results, here's information about Discounted Cash Flow (DCF) cost:

## Overview

Discounted cash flow (DCF) analysis is a method used to value a security, project, company, or asset, that incorporates the time value of money.(no content)In discount cash flow analysis, all future cash flows are estimated and discounted by using cost of capital to give their present values (PVs), and the sum of all future cash flows, both incoming and outgoing, is the net present value (NPV).

## Role of Cost of Capital

Discounting returns the present value of future cash flows, where the rate used is the cost of capital that appropriately reflects the risk, and timing, of the cash flows.(no content)The discount rate which is used in financial calculations is usually chosen to be equal to the cost of capital, and in a financial market equilibrium, the cost of capital will be the same as the market rate of return on the financial asset mixture the firm uses to finance capital investment.

## Common Applications

Discounted cash flow analysis is widely used in investment finance, real estate development, corporate financial management, and patent valuation.(no content)According to one version of the discounted cash flow valuation model, the intrinsic value of a company is the present value of all future expected free cash flows, computed by discounting the free cash flows at the company's weighted average cost of capital (WACC).

message_text:
Web search results for query: "Expected value mathematics"

Links: [{"title":"Expected value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value"},{"title":"Expectation value (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expectation_value_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Conditional expectation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_expectation"},{"title":"Law of total expectation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_total_expectation"},{"title":"Talk:Expected value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Expected_value"},{"title":"Variance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variance"},{"title":"Notation in probability and statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notation_in_probability_and_statistics"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Mathematics/2010 January 6 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Mathematics/2010_January_6"},{"title":"Expected value of sample information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value_of_sample_information"},{"title":"Martingale (probability theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martingale_(probability_theory)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of expected value in mathematics:

## Definition

In probability theory, the expected value (also called expectation, expectancy, expectation operator, mathematical expectation, mean, expectation value, or first moment) is a generalization of the weighted average.

## Basic Concept

The principle is that the value of a future gain should be directly proportional to the chance of getting it. In simpler terms, expected value represents the average outcome you would expect if an experiment or random event were repeated many times.

## Different Definitions

The simplest and original definition deals with the case of finitely many possible outcomes, such as in the flip of a coin. With the theory of infinite series, this can be extended to the case of countably many possible outcomes. It is also very common to consider the distinct case of random variables dictated by (piecewise-)continuous probability density functions, as these arise in many natural contexts.

## Historical Context

The use of the letter E to denote "expected value" goes back to W. A. Whitworth in 1901.

## Applications

Expected value is used in various contexts, including decision theory, risk analysis, and game theory to evaluate the long-term average of random outcomes weighted by their probabilities.

Links: [{"title":"Expected value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value"},{"title":"Expectation value (quantum mechanics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expectation_value_(quantum_mechanics)"},{"title":"Conditional expectation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Conditional_expectation"},{"title":"Law of total expectation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Law_of_total_expectation"},{"title":"Talk:Expected value - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Expected_value"},{"title":"Variance - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Variance"},{"title":"Notation in probability and statistics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Notation_in_probability_and_statistics"},{"title":"Wikipedia:Reference desk/Archives/Mathematics/2010 January 6 - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Wikipedia:Reference_desk/Archives/Mathematics/2010_January_6"},{"title":"Expected value of sample information - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value_of_sample_information"},{"title":"Martingale (probability theory) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Martingale_(probability_theory)"}]

Based on the search results, here's an overview of expected value in mathematics:

## Definition

In probability theory, the expected value (also called expectation, expectancy, expectation operator, mathematical expectation, mean, expectation value, or first moment) is a generalization of the weighted average.

## Basic Concept

The principle is that the value of a future gain should be directly proportional to the chance of getting it. In simpler terms, expected value represents the average outcome you would expect if an experiment or random event were repeated many times.

## Different Definitions

The simplest and original definition deals with the case of finitely many possible outcomes, such as in the flip of a coin. With the theory of infinite series, this can be extended to the case of countably many possible outcomes. It is also very common to consider the distinct case of random variables dictated by (piecewise-)continuous probability density functions, as these arise in many natural contexts.

## Historical Context

The use of the letter E to denote "expected value" goes back to W. A. Whitworth in 1901.

## Applications

Expected value is used in various contexts, including decision theory, risk analysis, and game theory to evaluate the long-term average of random outcomes weighted by their probabilities.

message_text:
## Summary

I've successfully completed the analysis of the paper "Constrained Markov Decision Processes". Here's what was accomplished:

**Paper Classification**: **Contribution** - The paper proposes new frameworks and methodologies for constrained MDPs with unbounded costs.

**Entities Extracted**: 7 triples identified and verified with Wikipedia articles:

1. **Markov decision process** (concept) - Proposes constrained variants and unified approaches
2. **Linear programming** (method) - Used to reduce the control problem to an infinite LP formulation
3. **Lagrange multiplier** (method) - Proposes a Lagrangian approach for sensitivity analysis
4. **Sensitivity analysis** (concept) - Obtains asymptotical results for the constrained control problem
5. **Expected value** (concept) - Studies expected average and total cost objectives
6. **Discounted cash flow** (concept) - Considers discounted cost as a special case
7. **Countable set** (concept) - Focuses on MDPs with countable state spaces

All Wikipedia URLs have been verified and the validation script confirms the JSON structure meets all requirements (with at least 1 "proposes" relation for a contribution paper, and proper entity type classification).

Sources:
- [Markov decision process](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Markov_decision_process)
- [Linear programming](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_programming)
- [Lagrange multiplier](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lagrange_multiplier)
- [Sensitivity analysis](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sensitivity_analysis)
- [Expected value](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Expected_value)
- [Discounted cash flow](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Discounted_cash_flow)
- [Countable set](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Countable_set)
